awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Categorifying Quantum Three-Manifold Invariants
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum topology is a branch of mathematics that provides a testing ground for the structures needed in a quantum theory of gravity. This field has brought about unprecedented interaction between mathematics and theoretical physics. It has been extremely successful and well studied in 3-dimensions. However, since we live in 4-dimensions (including time), a full theory of quantum gravity requires an extension of these tools to 4-dimensions. An emerging mathematical philosophy known as "categorification" provides an avenue to uncover a hidden layer in mathematical structures, revealing a richer and more robust theory capable of describing more complex phenomenon.  This project will use the perspective of categorification to enhance one of the most successful theories in 3-dimensions to a full 4-dimensional theory.

This collaboration will harness the interplay between low-dimensional geometry, representation theory, and higher-dimensional gauge theory. Through this coordinated effort the PIs will make substantial progress on the problem of categorifying 3-manifold invariants. The PIs will capitalize on recent breakthroughs in theoretical physics and higher representation theory that have created new possibilities for significant progress on this problem.  Among the techniques to be employed include:  fivebrane compactifications to provide a universal description of various old and new homological invariants of 3-manifolds, the use of infinity categories for defining tensor products of higher representations of quantum groups, and the theory of Hopfological algebra for categorifications at roots of unity, as well as recent work on odd link homology theory and categorifications of Habiro's universal invariant.

por.por_cntn:
During the entire course of this award, PI Gukov introduced and explored new invariants of 3-manifolds that bridge different areas of mathematics --- topology, geometry, and representation theory --- in new ways. Such bridges are always valuable as they allow to approach a given problem from several different perspectives. They also make mathematics a more unified science, in particular by bringing different math communities together.

In the present case, the work supported by this award also builds new bridges to quantum physics and machine learning. The bridges to quantum physics involve the mathematical tools that are required for counting black hole microstates, a subject seemingly different from topology of 3-dimensional manifolds. And the new bridges to machine learning involve a new and fast growing effort to use AI in problems of fundamental science, in particular, in low-dimensional topology. Specifically, using reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms --- such as A3C, A2C, and TRPO --- and various architectures (e.g. Transformer and Reformer) the work supported by this award led to user-friendly open-source tools that allow to study topologically interesting properties of knots up to 70 or even 100 crossings, whereas traditional computational tools of quantum invariants are typically limited by 15 crossings or so.

Similarly, the new invariants of 3-manifolds --- introduced in a joint work with Pei, Putrov, and Vafa, and developed further in other collaborations, including several supported by this award --- bridge two different worlds within quantum topology. One world, based on algebraic structures called quantum groups (at generic q) involves infinite-dimensional representations (Verma modules) related to other area of algebra: vertex operator algebras, geometric Langlands correspondence, among others. The other world is more topology-oriented and often goes by the name “categorification”: it aims to study the so-called homological invariants of knots and 3-manifolds, which turn out to be extremely useful for many problems in low-dimensional topology. While there is a fairly large number of homological invariants of knots, one of the main challenges in this area is to construct homological invariants of 3-manifolds, which until so far are limited to Heegaard Floer homology and its variants.

The work supported by this award partly fills this gap by constructing new 3-manifold invariants that should admit a categorification, i.e. the q-series invariant studied in this work should be a graded Euler characteristic of a doubly graded homology. For a given 3-manifold, this homology theory is also expected to be a function of Spin-C structures, which in the future is likely to provide yet another bridge to Heegaard Floer homology. Very recently, an important step in this direction was made by Akhmechet, Johnson, and Krushkal. Vyacheslav Krushkal was one of the discussion leaders at the regular “idea incubator” meeting at Caltech, in part supported by this award, stimulating many discussions and ideas for future work.
